description: From Middle English menen (‚Äúto intend; remember; lament; comfort‚Äù), from Old English m«£nan (‚Äúto mean, complain‚Äù), Proto-West Germanic *mainijan, from Proto-Germanic *mainijanƒÖ (‚Äúto mean, think; complain‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *meyn- (‚Äúto think‚Äù), or perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *meyno-, extended form of Proto-Indo-European *mey-.

Germanic cognates include West Frisian miene (‚Äúto deem, think‚Äù) (Old Frisian mƒìna (‚Äúto signify‚Äù)), Dutch menen (‚Äúto believe, think, mean‚Äù) (Middle Dutch menen (‚Äúto think, intend‚Äù)), German meinen (‚Äúto think, mean, believe‚Äù), Old Saxon mƒìnian. Indo-European cognates include Old Irish m√≠an (‚Äúwish, desire‚Äù) and Polish mieniƒá (‚Äúto signify, believe‚Äù). Related to moan.

verbs.description: mean (third-person singular simple present means, present participle meaning, simple past and past participle meant)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To intend, to plan (to do); to have as one's intention. [from 8th c.]
examples: I didn't mean to knock your tooth out.
I mean to go to Baddeck this summer.
I meant to take the car in for a smog check, but it slipped my mind.
The authors meant a challenge to the status quo.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have as intentions of a given kind. [from 14th c.]
examples: Don't be angry; she meant well.

entries.meaning: (transitive, usually in passive) To intend (something) for a given purpose or fate; to predestine. [from 16th c.]
examples: Actually this desk was meant for the subeditor.
Man was not meant to question such things.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To intend an ensuing comment or statement as an explanation.[1]
examples: Your reasoning seems needlessly abstruse, complex, and verbose for me. I mean, could you dumb it down for my sake?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To convey (a given sense); to signify, or indicate (an object or idea). [from 8th c.]
examples: The sky is red this morning‚Äîdoes that mean we're in for a storm?

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of a word, symbol etc: to have reference to, to signify. [from 8th c.]
examples: What does this hieroglyph mean?

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of a person (or animal etc): to intend to express, to imply, to hint at, to allude.
examples: I'm afraid I don't understand what you mean.
He is a little different, if you know what I mean.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To have conviction in (something said or expressed); to be sincere in (what one says). [from 18th c.]
examples: Does she really mean what she said to him last night?
Say what you mean and mean what you say.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause or produce (a given result); to bring about (a given result). [from 19th c.]
examples: One faltering step means certain death.

entries.meaning: (usually with to) To be of some level of importance.
examples: That little dog meant everything to me.
Formality and titles mean nothing in their circle.

verbs.description: mean (third-person singular simple present means, present participle meaning, simple past and past participle meaned)

entries.meaning: (Ireland, UK regional) To lament.
examples: Thanne morned Mede ¬∑ and mened hire to the kynge / To haue space to speke ¬∑ spede if she my»ùte.

description: From Middle English mene, imene, from Old English m«£ne, ƒ°em«£ne (‚Äúcommon, public, general, universal‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *gamainƒ´, from Proto-Germanic *gamainiz (‚Äúcommon‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *mey- (‚Äúto change, exchange, share‚Äù).

Cognate with West Frisian mien (‚Äúgeneral, universal‚Äù), Dutch gemeen (‚Äúcommon, mean‚Äù), German gemein (‚Äúcommon, mean, nasty‚Äù), Danish gemen, Gothic êå≤êå∞êåºêå∞êåπêåΩêçÉ (gamains, ‚Äúcommon, unclean‚Äù), Latin comm≈´nis (‚Äúshared, common, general‚Äù) (Old Latin comoinem).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Common; general.
Of a common or low origin, grade, or quality; common; humble.
examples: a man of mean parentage
a mean abode

entries.meaning: Low in quality or degree; inferior; poor; shabby.
examples: Synonyms: cheap, grotty; see also Thesaurus:low-quality
a mean appearance
a mean dress

entries.meaning: Without dignity of mind; destitute of honour; low-minded; spiritless; base.
examples: Synonyms: base, ignoble, selfish, unkind, vile
Antonyms: lofty, noble, honorable
a mean motive
It was mean of you to steal that little girl's piggy bank.

entries.meaning: Of little value or worth; worthy of little or no regard; contemptible; despicable.
(chiefly UK) Ungenerous; stingy; tight-fisted.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:stingy
He's so mean. I've never seen him spend so much as five pounds on presents for his children.

entries.meaning: Disobliging; pettily offensive or unaccommodating.
Intending to cause harm, successfully or otherwise; bearing ill will towards another.
examples: Synonyms: cruel, malicious, nasty
Watch out for her, she's mean. I said good morning to her, and she punched me in the nose.

entries.meaning: Powerful; fierce; strong.
examples: Synonyms: harsh, damaging, fierce
It must have been a mean typhoon that levelled this town.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Accomplished with great skill; deft; hard to compete with.
examples: Synonyms: deft, skillful, top-notch
Your mother can roll a mean cigarette.
He hits a mean backhand.

entries.meaning: (informal, often childish) Difficult, tricky.
examples: This problem is mean!

description: From Middle English meene, borrowed from Old French meien (French moyen), Late Latin mediƒÅnus (‚Äúthat is in the middle, middle‚Äù), from Latin medius (‚Äúmiddle‚Äù). Cognate with mid. For the musical sense, compare the cognate Italian mezzano. Doublet of median and mizzen.

entries.meaning: Having the mean (see noun below) as its value; average.
examples: The mean family has 2.4 children.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Middling; intermediate; moderately good, tolerable.
examples: I have declared in the causes what harm costiveness hath done in procuring this disease; if it be so noxious, the opposite must needs be good, or mean at least, as indeed it is¬†[‚Ä¶].

entries.meaning: (now chiefly in the plural) A method or course of action used to achieve some result. [from 14th c.]
examples: To say truth, it is a meane full of uncertainty and danger.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, in the singular) An intermediate step or intermediate steps.
examples: Verily in this treatise this hath been mine only purpose; and the mean to bring the same to effect hath been such as whereby I studied to profit wholesomely, not to please delicately.

entries.meaning: Something which is intermediate or in the middle; an intermediate value or range of values; a medium. [from 14th c.]
examples: It presents a sort of mean between speech and song, continually inclining towards the latter, never altogether leaving its hold on the former; it is speech, though always attuned speech, in passages of average interest and importance; it is song, though always distinct and articulate song, in passages demanding more fervid utterance.

entries.meaning: (music, now historical) The middle part of three-part polyphonic music; now specifically, the alto part in polyphonic music; an alto instrument. [from 15th c.]
examples: Of these [rattles] they have Base, Tenor, Countertenor, Meane, and Treble.

entries.meaning: (statistics) The average of a set of values, calculated by summing them together and dividing by the number of terms; the arithmetic mean. [from 15th c.]
(mathematics) Any function of multiple variables that satisfies certain properties and yields a number representative of its arguments; or, the number so yielded; a measure of central tendency.
examples: Note that (1.41) is simply the probability-weighted mean without any explicit allowance for the stratification; each observation is weighted by its inflation factor and the total divided by the total of the inflation factors for the survey.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Either of the two numbers in the middle of a conventionally presented proportion, as 2 and 3 in 1:2=3:6.
examples: ...if four numbers be in proportion, the product of the first and last, or of the two extremes, is equal to the product of the second and third, or of the two means.
